Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Tornado-Resilient Structural Retrofits for Sustainable Housing Communities

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objectives of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) program award are to characterize tornadic wind loads on a residential building and to compare the resultant structural response of traditional construction against a structurally enhanced one. Study variables include both tornado parameters (vortex size, forward speed, pressure profile and swirl ratio), and the building parameters (building location relative to the tornado core, structural connections, and the main wind force resisting system). A 3-dimensional Finite Element Analysis model of a light-framed residential structural system will be used as the prototype to establish structural response. A database-assisted design (DAD) methodology will be used to analyze tornadic wind load time-histories from a model building shape and determine critical design loads and reactions for the structural system. Full-scale tests will be conducted on corner substructures of the prototype building for validating the numerical model and also to evaluate the structural and economic benefits of enhanced structural systems in houses. The effort will provide the basis for a tornado-resilient design methodology for houses.

The award facilitates knowledge generation that provides a better understanding of the structural behaviors and vulnerability of existing wood-framed houses, while identifying benefits to a community that incorporate tornado-resilient building structural systems. A
new graduate-level course, Engineered Design of Sustainable Residential Structures will provide knowledge to civil engineering graduate students, and enable them to interact with residential building contractors, and structural engineers. Information on tornadic loads and structural enhancement of houses will be made available to builders via webbased portals. A Wind Hazard Damage Assessment Group will be formed to conduct post-storm assessments and to disseminate research findings on advanced residential construction practices. Through research immersion, K-12 science teachers will develop high-school teaching modules on tornado damage to houses for inclusion in high-school science curricula. Training and mentorship of a PhD student will be provided in experimental and analytical studies. This award will provide resources that will be used to develop technologies to improve performance of low-rise buildings affected by tornadoes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tornadoes are a natural part of the American experience, although contemporary communities still know too little about them. In the early seventeenth century, Massachusetts Governor John Winthrop documented the first tornado in 1630, writing that it was “so violent for half an hour as it blew down multitudes of trees. It lifted up their meeting house at Newbury, the people being in it.” And although over 1,000 tornadoes occur every year in the U.S. the Weather Bureau, (precursor to the National Weather Service) once banned the word “tornado” from their weather broadcasts, because they felt it would elicit widespread panic. It is only within the last fifty years that we have developed technologies to predict when tornadoes are likely to occur.  In this project our research addressed the intractable problems needed to better understand the forces generated on buildings and to develop tornado-resilient communities. 

The damage to residential structures from tornadoes is a large problem that has received inadequate attention from the structural engineering community.  Extreme tornadoes (of EF4 strength and higher) create substantial destruction in communities. By far residential structures bear a disproportionately large portion of the losses. In 2011 two deadly tornadoes, hit Tuscaloosa, AL and Joplin, MO resulting in over 220 fatalities and $6B in economic losses. These events were the urgent motivators for initiating this research.  Project goals were to collect data to help understand the interactions of tornadoes with residential structures, to develop approaches for predicting the magnitude of damage and to educate engineers, building professionals and communities about the design provisions and technologies to mitigate losses.

The project’s primary objective was to determine and quantify the tornado-induced loads on residential structures. This is the first required step to developing design guidelines for these structures.   Starting with very limited data on the strength of tornadoes or wind speed variations within them, we primarily used two sources, the experimental results from Iowa State University’s Tornado Simulator, and forensic information collected following several tornadoes. The tornado simulator data consisted of surface pressure coefficients on buildings impacted by a tornado-like vortex that enabled us to estimate the wind loads on exterior walls and roofs of buildings. We collected geo-located information for tornado-damaged structures in several locations including Moore 2013, and Dallas 2015.  In parallel to these activities, the project also developed a theoretical tornado using mathematical principles of vortex behavior which enabled the prediction of peak wind velocities throughout the footprint of a tornado path. Ultimately we created mechanisms to predict/estimate tornado wind loads, which have contributed to larger national thrusts of the inclusion of tornado design wind guideline that was included into the ASCE 7-16 Minimum Design Guide for Buildings.

A major contribution of the research project has been the development of its human capital; undergraduate and graduate students and teachers. The project supported two PhD dissertations, one MS (non-thesis), two undergraduate Honors theses.  One of the PhD students, Dr. David B. Roueche was awarded an NSF GRFP, further leveraging the work to better understand tornadoes. He is currently a tenure-track Assistant Professor at Auburn University.  The project supported eight undergraduate researchers, including two as REUs and two from Brazil. The four UF undergraduates all went on to graduate school, three pursuing their PhDs. I am pleased to note in 2018, Mr. Jason Lopez, a University of Florida undergraduate civil engineering student was awarded the second NSF GRFP.  In addition, the project hosted two middle-school teachers during the summers, who developed curricula disseminating wind hazard knowledge to students.

The project was initiated during a period of resurging interest in wind hazards and community resilience, and this research addressed these needs in a very unique way.  The PI formed a Wind Hazard Damage Assessment Group (WHDAG) that had as its purpose educating and training of students on wind engineering and natural hazards.  The WHDAG self-published 17 Preliminary Damage Reports following the occurrences of tornadoes, hurricanes and straight-line wind events over the past six years.  These online documents were targeted at the wind engineering and meteorological communities and the communities that were directly affected by the event.  All reports were researched, edited and published within 48-hours of the tornado or wind event. There were several tornado-design workshops hosted throughout the mid-west, targeting building professionals and contractors in those regions.

So far, the project’s yield includes 2 monographs (on Joplin, MO and the Moore, OK tornadoes), 14 peer-reviewed papers, 40 conference papers or presentations, 7 posters and three media interviews, including one on NPR’s Science Friday program. In 2015, Moore, OK became the first US community to adopt tornado-resilient structural design provisions. Positive change, stimulated in part by this research, is underway.
